segments.en: Numbered Discourses 4
20. The Great Chapter
196. With Sāḷha

segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

segments.pli: Atha kho sāḷho ca licchavi abhayo ca licchavi yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho sāḷho licchavi bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then Sāḷha and Abhaya the Licchavis went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

segments.pli: “Santi, bhante, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā dvayena oghassa nittharaṇaṃ paññapenti—
segments.en: “There are, sir, some ascetics and brahmins who advocate crossing the flood by means of two things:
purification of ethics, and mortification in disgust of sin.
What does the Buddha say about this?”

segments.pli: “Sīlavisuddhiṃ kho ahaṃ, sāḷha, aññataraṃ sāmaññaṅganti vadāmi.
segments.en: “Sāḷha, purification of ethics is one of the factors of the ascetic life, I say.

segments.pli: Ye te, sāḷha, samaṇabrāhmaṇā tapojigucchāvādā tapojigucchāsārā tapojigucchāallīnā viharanti, abhabbā te oghassa nittharaṇāya.
segments.en: But those ascetics and brahmins who teach mortification in disgust of sin—regarding it as essential and clinging to it—are incapable of crossing the flood.

segments.pli: Yepi te, sāḷha, samaṇabrāhmaṇā aparisuddhakāyasamācārā aparisuddhavacīsamācārā aparisuddhamanosamācārā aparisuddhājīvā, abhabbā te ñāṇadassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya.
segments.en: And those ascetics and brahmins whose behavior by way of body, speech, and mind is not pure are also incapable of knowing and seeing, of supreme awakening.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, sāḷha, puriso nadiṃ taritukāmo tiṇhaṃ kuṭhāriṃ ādāya vanaṃ paviseyya.
segments.en: Suppose a man who wanted to cross a river took a sharp axe into a wood.

segments.pli: So tattha passeyya mahatiṃ sālalaṭṭhiṃ ujuṃ navaṃ akukkuccakajātaṃ.
segments.en: There he’d see a large green sal tree, straight and young and grown free of defects.
He’d cut it down at the base,
cut off the top,
and completely strip off the branches and foliage.
Then he’d trim it with axes and
machetes,
plane it,
and sand it with a rock.
Finally, he’d launch out on the river.
What do you think, Sāḷha?

segments.pli: bhabbo nu kho so puriso nadiṃ taritun”ti?
segments.en: Is that man capable of crossing the river?”
“No, sir.
Why not?

segments.pli: “Asu hi, bhante, sālalaṭṭhi bahiddhā suparikammakatā anto avisuddhā.
segments.en: Because that green sal tree is well worked on the outside, but inside it’s still not cleared out.

segments.pli: Tassetaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—sālalaṭṭhi saṃsīdissati, puriso anayabyasanaṃ āpajjissatī”ti.
segments.en: I’d expect that green sal tree to sink, and the man to come to ruin.”

segments.pli: “Evamevaṃ kho, sāḷha, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā tapojigucchāvādā tapojigucchāsārā tapojigucchāallīnā viharanti, abhabbā te oghassa nittharaṇāya.
segments.en: “In the same way, Sāḷha, those ascetics and brahmins who teach mortification in disgust of sin—regarding it as essential and clinging to it—are incapable of crossing the flood.

segments.pli: Yepi te, sāḷha, samaṇabrāhmaṇā aparisuddhakāyasamācārā aparisuddhavacīsamācārā aparisuddhamanosamācārā aparisuddhājīvā, abhabbā te ñāṇadassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya.
segments.en: And those ascetics and brahmins whose behavior by way of body, speech, and mind is not pure are also incapable of knowing and seeing, of supreme awakening.

segments.pli: Ye ca kho te, sāḷha, samaṇabrāhmaṇā na tapojigucchāvādā na tapojigucchāsārā na tapojigucchāallīnā viharanti, bhabbā te oghassa nittharaṇāya.
segments.en: But those ascetics and brahmins who don’t teach mortification in disgust of sin—not regarding it as essential or clinging to it—are capable of crossing the flood.

segments.pli: Yepi te, sāḷha, samaṇabrāhmaṇā parisuddhakāyasamācārā parisuddhavacīsamācārā parisuddhamanosamācārā parisuddhājīvā, bhabbā te ñāṇadassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya.
segments.en: And those ascetics and brahmins whose behavior by way of body, speech, and mind is pure are also capable of knowing and seeing, of supreme awakening.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, sāḷha, puriso nadiṃ taritukāmo tiṇhaṃ kuṭhāriṃ ādāya vanaṃ paviseyya.
segments.en: Suppose a man who wanted to cross a river took a sharp axe into a wood.

segments.pli: So tattha passeyya mahatiṃ sālalaṭṭhiṃ ujuṃ navaṃ akukkuccakajātaṃ.
segments.en: There he’d see a large green sal tree, straight and young and grown free of defects.
He’d cut it down at the base,
cut off the top,
and completely strip off the branches and foliage.
Then he’d trim it with axes and
machetes.

segments.pli: vāsīhi tacchetvā nikhādanaṃ ādāya anto suvisodhitaṃ visodheyya;
segments.en: Then he’d take a chisel and completely clear it out inside.
Then he’d plane it,
sand it with a rock,
and make it into a boat.
Finally he’d fix it with oars and rudder,
and launch out on the river.
What do you think, Sāḷha?

segments.pli: bhabbo nu kho so puriso nadiṃ taritun”ti?
segments.en: Is that man capable of crossing the river?”
“Yes, sir.
Why is that?

segments.pli: “Asu hi, bhante, sālalaṭṭhi bahiddhā suparikammakatā, anto suvisuddhā nāvākatā phiyārittabaddhā.
segments.en: Because that green sal tree is well worked on the outside, cleared out on the inside, made into a boat, and fixed with oars and rudder.
I’d expect

segments.pli: ‘nāvā na saṃsīdissati, puriso sotthinā pāraṃ gamissatī’”ti.
segments.en: that boat to not sink, and the man to safely make it to the far shore.”

segments.pli: “Evamevaṃ kho, sāḷha, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā na tapojigucchāvādā na tapojigucchāsārā na tapojigucchāallīnā viharanti, bhabbā te oghassa nittharaṇāya.
segments.en: “In the same way, Sāḷha, those ascetics and brahmins who don’t teach mortification in disgust of sin—not regarding it as essential or clinging to it—are capable of crossing the flood.

segments.pli: Yepi te, sāḷha, samaṇabrāhmaṇā parisuddhakāyasamācārā parisuddhavacīsamācārā parisuddhamanosamācārā parisuddhājīvā, bhabbā te ñāṇadassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya.
segments.en: And those ascetics and brahmins whose behavior by way of body, speech, and mind is pure are also capable of knowing and seeing, of supreme awakening.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, sāḷha, yodhājīvo bahūni cepi kaṇḍacitrakāni jānāti;
segments.en: Suppose there was a warrior who knew lots of fancy archery tricks.

segments.pli: atha kho so tīhi ṭhānehi rājāraho hoti rājabhoggo, rañño aṅganteva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
segments.en: It is only with these three factors that he becomes worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and is considered a factor of kingship.
What three?

segments.pli: Dūrepātī ca, akkhaṇavedhī ca, mahato ca kāyassa padāletā.
segments.en: He’s a long-distance shooter, a marksman, and one who shatters large objects.
Just as a warrior is a long-distance shooter,

segments.pli: evamevaṃ kho, sāḷha, ariyasāvako sammāsamādhi hoti.
segments.en: a noble disciple has right immersion.

segments.pli: Sammāsamādhi, sāḷha, ariyasāvako yaṃ kiñci rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā sabbaṃ rūpaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
segments.en: A noble disciple with right immersion truly sees any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: *all* form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
They truly see any kind of feeling …
perception …
choices …

segments.pli: yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ viññāṇaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
segments.en: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near, *all* consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
Just as a warrior is a marksman,

segments.pli: evamevaṃ kho, sāḷha, ariyasāvako sammādiṭṭhi hoti.
segments.en: a noble disciple has right view.

segments.pli: Sammādiṭṭhi, sāḷha, ariyasāvako ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti … pe … ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
segments.en: A noble disciple with right view truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, sāḷha, yodhājīvo mahato kāyassa padāletā;
segments.en: Just as a warrior shatters large objects,

segments.pli: evamevaṃ kho, sāḷha, ariyasāvako sammāvimutti hoti.
segments.en: a noble disciple has right freedom.

segments.pli: Sammāvimutti, sāḷha, ariyasāvako mahantaṃ avijjākkhandhaṃ padāletī”ti.
segments.en: A noble disciple with right freedom shatters the great mass of ignorance.”
